steps.title: Choose ripe bananas that are brick red and smell sweet.
steps.content: Choose ripe bananas that are brick red and smell sweet. [3] X Research source You can also feel the bananas, as the ripe ones will give when you press lightly on them. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Cut off the ends of the banana and slice the banana lengthwise.
steps.content: Cut off the ends of the banana and slice the banana lengthwise. Slice all the way down to each end for easy removal, and use a cutting board to protect your counters. [5] X Research source If you’ve succeeded at finding a ripe banana, it’s flesh should be ivory white when you peel it at home. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the banana from its peel.
steps.content: Remove the banana from its peel. Now that the peel is sliced, slide the banana out and throw away or compost the peel.

steps.title: Slice the banana up or consume it as is.
steps.content: Slice the banana up or consume it as is. Put sliced banana in a bowl and eat it with a fork to minimize messiness. You can pair the sliced banana with other berries, to complement the sweet, raspberry undertones of red bananas. [7] X Research source You may note that the banana feels a bit softer than your average yellow banana, and that’s completely normal. [8] X Research source For a special dessert, put whipped cream and chocolate drizzle on the sliced banana. For breakfast, top off a bowl of cereal or yogurt with the sliced red banana.

steps.title: Cook 1⁄2 cup (120 mL) oats 5 minutes ahead of making the smoothie.
steps.content: Cook 1 ⁄ 2 cup (120 mL) oats 5 minutes ahead of making the smoothie. You can cook oats on the stovetop or in the microwave. Doing this 5 minutes beforehand will give the oats time to cool. Use high-protein oatmeal for extra protein in your smoothie.

steps.title: Add the peeled and sliced banana to the blender.
steps.content: Add the peeled and sliced banana to the blender. To peel, use a knife to cut off the ends of the banana and then cut the banana longways. Remove the banana from the peel, and slice it into pieces. Slice thinly for faster blending.

steps.title: Add the cooled, cooked oats to the blender.
steps.content: Add the cooled, cooked oats to the blender. If the oats aren’t quite cool yet, add a couple of pieces of ice to the smoothie to balance out the heat.

steps.title: Pour in 1 cup (240 mL) almond milk over the oats and red banana.
steps.content: Pour in 1 cup (240 mL) almond milk over the oats and red banana. If you don’t like almond milk, you can substitute in soy, coconut, oat or regular milk. Almond milk is a rich source of calcium, vitamin E, and folic acid, which will contribute to the immune-boosting qualities of the smoothie. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Blend the ingredients, adding ice for additional thickness.
steps.content: Blend the ingredients, adding ice for additional thickness. Blend until the ingredients liquefy and taste the smoothie to check if it’s smooth enough. Add ice until you achieve desired thickness. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and butter and flour the pan.
steps.content: Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and butter and flour the pan. Spread butter along the bottom and edges of the pan, using a paper towel to help distribute the butter if necessary. Sprinkle flour over the entirety of the pan.

steps.title: Whisk flour, salt, baking soda, and ginger in a small bowl.
steps.content: Whisk flour, salt, baking soda, and ginger in a small bowl. Mix 1 2 ⁄ 3 cups (390 mL) all purpose flour, 1 ⁄ 4 teaspoon (1.2 mL) teaspoon salt, 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) baking soda, and 1 ⁄ 2 teaspoon (2.5 mL) ground ginger until combined, checking for a similar color makeup throughout the mix.

steps.title: Use an electric mixer to beat 1 cup (240 mL) sugar and 2 eggs in a large bowl for 4 minutes.
steps.content: Use an electric mixer to beat 1 cup (240 mL) sugar and 2 eggs in a large bowl for 4 minutes. Beat until the eggs and sugar are a lighter color and appear thick.

steps.title: Beat in 1 tsp (4.9 mL) vanilla extract and 1⁄4 cup (59 mL) vegetable oil.
steps.content: Beat in 1 tsp (4.9 mL) vanilla extract and 1 ⁄ 4 cup (59 mL) vegetable oil. Beat with the electric mixture for about 30 seconds.

steps.title: Stir in 1⁄4 cup (59 mL) crushed pineapple and 1 1⁄2 cups (350 mL) mashed red bananas.
steps.content: Stir in 1 ⁄ 4 cup (59 mL) crushed pineapple and 1 1 ⁄ 2 cups (350 mL) mashed red bananas. Set the electric mixer to the side, and grab a spoon to stir in these larger ingredients. Stir until evenly distributed throughout the mixture. You can mash up the banana in a bowl with a fork. For the pineapple, put pineapple chunks in the blender and set the blender on chop for 30 seconds. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Stir in the flour mixture from the small bowl until evenly incorporated.
steps.content: Stir in the flour mixture from the small bowl until evenly incorporated. Fold the dough as you stir to make sure flour reaches each part of the mix. Scrape flour off the sides of the bowl periodically.

steps.title: Pour dough into the prepared pan and spread evenly.
steps.content: Pour dough into the prepared pan and spread evenly. Use a spoon or your hands to spread the dough, until it sits evenly throughout the pan. You’re done with most of the hands on work, and can now wash your hands free of food.

steps.title: Bake the bread for 1 hour or until golden-brown.
steps.content: Bake the bread for 1 hour or until golden-brown. Check the bread after the hour to see if the top is golden. If it is, remove the bread with hand mitts, and stick a fork or cake tester into it. If the fork comes back clean, the bread is ready. If not, stick it back in the oven for 5 minutes and check again. If you have any leftover bread after serving, store it in a tupperware container or cover with aluminum foil and keep in the fridge.
